title: Citi says counter-cyclical mining M&A only for the brave
text:
Citi's analysts reckon Mick Davis's X2 Resources is the only private name looking to do anything of size in mining. Supplied by Sarah Thompson Anthony Macdonald Jake Mitchell Citi's metals and mining team has poured cold water on any chance that the big miners may embark on a counter-cyclical merger and acquisition spree, saying deals may be restricted to the mid-tier sector.
In a note to clients on Monday morning, Citi said subdued metal prices and weak share prices had left investors wondering whether the sector was set for another M&A cycle.
"We are skeptical," the analysts told clients.
"We do not anticipate a return of large-cap M&A â€“ substantial impairments and increased shareholder pressure for returns are preventing current management from acting and are likely to lead to further divestments ('births'), in our view.
Citi said subdued metal prices and weak share prices had left investors wondering whether the sector was set for another M&A cycle. Citi "The mid-tier sector may see more action, as the struggle to be relevant or to stay in business in a lower commodity price environment may force consolidation ('deaths')."
And as for private equity's involvement, the analysts reckon Mick Davis's X2 Resources is the only private name looking to do anything of size.
Citi said historically, M&A transactions had a strong correlation to commodity prices, with rising prices boosting share prices and making it easier for acquirers to fund deals.
The note comes only a fortnight after Citi found big miners had written off about 90 per cent of the value of assets acquired since 2007.
